messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Papers
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I think what Alan is alluding to is that there is fair evidence that at some time in I think the 70 s or 80 s, at one of the outer Tokyo branches,
messages.messageBody:
Hi all, I think what Alan is alluding to is that there is fair
evidence that at some time in I think the 70's or 80's, at one of the
outer Tokyo branches, there was quite a bit of influence being exerted
by some unsavoury criminal elements on some of the judges, to get their
swords through, and this resulted in green papers being issued on swords
they shouldn't. That at least is how I understand it.

It was also only after a certain time, like in the last 10 years that
they were in existence, or something like that.

I have always been of the opinion that if it has a green paper, re
submit it for a Hozon. Don't forget that new evidence on a smith or
school could have since come to light and or new thinking may be in
place and you may get a different result regardless if the paper is good
or bad.

Cheers

Rich

On 14/09/2010 2:19 AM, Ron Hartmann wrote:
>
> Alan, you're not saying that all Tokubetsu Kicho papers are
> unacceptable, are you? My impression is that the NBTHK simply
> tightened the reins on what gets what paper. Like something mumei that
> was given the lowest level "white" paper would never be papered, today
> (because of a lack of quality). I'm not sure where the next level
> (Tokubetsu Kicho) fits today but Koshu Tokubetsu Kicho would be like
> today's Hozon level and some earlier Juyo Token might only get
> Tokubetsu Hozon, today. Something like that.
>
> Ron
> STL

> names. I stopped this practice a few years ago at Christie's London but it
> still takes place on occasion elsewhere.
>
> Alan

>

messages.messageBody:

Rich

Has the NBTHK found its way out of its troubles yet?

And how did it lose its government approved status?

messages.subject: Re: Papers
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, you re not saying that all Tokubetsu Kicho papers are unacceptable, are you? My impression is that the NBTHK simply tightened the reins on what gets what
messages.messageBody:
Alan, you're not saying that all Tokubetsu Kicho papers are unacceptable, are you? My impression is that the NBTHK simply tightened the reins on what gets what paper. Like something mumei that was given the lowest level "white" paper would never be papered, today (because of a lack of quality). I'm not sure where the next level (Tokubetsu Kicho) fits today but Koshu Tokubetsu Kicho would be like today's Hozon level and some earlier Juyo Token might only get Tokubetsu Hozon, today. Something like that.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Alan Bale
To: nihontostudy ; token_kenkyu_kai@...
Sent: Monday, September 13, 2010 1:00 PM
Subject: Papers


On the subject of papers collectors should be aware that one or two
unscrupulus Japanese dealers have been entering blades with Tokubetsu
Kicho papers into western auction houses, these blades having been refused
by recent (Hozon etc) shinsa panels, some of these blades were by big
names. I stopped this practice a few years ago at Christie's London but it
still takes place on occasion elsewhere.

Alan



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Papers
messages.msgSnippet: Are we saying all Tokubetsu Kisho papered blades have issues? I was not aware that was the case. Can you elaborate, Alan? Or how would one tell a good blade
messages.messageBody:
Are we saying all Tokubetsu Kisho papered blades have issues? I was not
aware that was the case. Can you elaborate, Alan? Or how would one tell a
good blade with such papers from one that was 'refused by recent (Hozon etc)
shinsa panels'?

Best,

Andres
